abstract: pmc Sci Rep Sci Rep 1579 scirep Scientific Reports 2045-2322 Nature Publishing Group PMC12484968 PMC12484968.1 12484968 12484968 41027977 10.1038/s41598-025-04047-8 4047 1 Article Ultrasound guided retrolaminar block reduces postoperative gastrointestinal system dysfunctions during percutaneous nephrolithotomy: a prospective, randomised, double-blind, clinical study Bayindir Serpil 1 Yildirim Kadir kadir.yildirim@sbu.edu.tr 2 1 https://ror.org/03k7bde87 grid.488643.5 0000 0004 5894 3909 Department Of Anesthesiology And Reanimation, Health Sciences University, Elazig Fethi Sekin SUAM, 2 https://ror.org/03k7bde87 grid.488643.5 0000 0004 5894 3909 Department Of Urology, Health Sciences University, Elazig Fethi Sekin SUAM, 30 9 2025 2025 15 478255 33802 5 3 2025 23 5 2025 30 09 2025 02 10 2025 02 10 2025 © The Author(s) 2025 2025 https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ Open Access http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ We aimed to determine the postoperative gastrointestinal tract dysfunction and intraoperative hemodynamic effects of ultrasound-guided retrolaminar block in patients undergoing percutaneous nephrolithotomy. Fifty-eight adult patients were randomly divided into 2 groups preoperatively: Group RLB ( n n p p p Keywords Retrolaminar block Percutaneous nephrolithotomy Gastrointestinal tract dysfunctions I-FEED score Perlas score Subject terms Gastroenterology Urology https://doi.org/10.13039/501100004410 Türkiye Bilimsel ve Teknolojik Araştırma Kurumu pmc-status-qastatus 0 pmc-status-live yes pmc-status-embargo no pmc-status-released yes pmc-prop-open-access yes pmc-prop-olf no pmc-prop-manuscript no pmc-prop-legally-suppressed no pmc-prop-has-pdf yes pmc-prop-has-supplement no pmc-prop-pdf-only no pmc-prop-suppress-copyright no pmc-prop-is-real-version no pmc-prop-is-scanned-article no pmc-prop-preprint no pmc-prop-in-epmc yes issue-copyright-statement © Springer Nature Limited 2025 Introduction General anesthesia has a number of effects that produce gastrointestinal tract (GI) dysfunction in the postoperative period. These effects are related to a variety of factors ranging from the pharmacological properties of anesthesia agents to the neurohumoral effects triggered by surgical stress. Common GI dysfunctions include nausea and vomiting; abdominal distension due to decreased intestinal peristalsis and postoperative inflammatory response; delayed gastric emptying; ileus; fatigue; and delayed initiation of oral feeding. These conditions may lead to prolonged hospital stay, increased treatment costs and decreased patient comfort 1 2 Percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL) is the minimally invasive surgical technique of choice for large (> 2 cm) and complex kidney stones. Using a rigid nephroscope, percutaneous access is established, and staghorn calculi gradually fragmented and removed 3 4 5 6 7 8 In this study, we aimed to determine the postoperative GI and intraoperative hemodynamic effects of USG-guided RLB in patients undergoing PCNL. Methodology Study design and settings This was a randomized prospective single center clinical study that aimed to evaluate the likely changes in GI functions postoperative period in patients undergoing PCNL. The study was conducted in Elazığ Fethi Sekin City Hospital (Türkiye) between January and March 2025. The study protocol was approved by the local ethics committee decision no: 26,959 (11/09/2024) and the Clinical Trials registration was submitted on 22/01/2025 and its ID number was NCT06787898 1 Participants A total of 58 patients aged 18–65 years with body mass index (BMI) of 25–39 (kg/m²) and American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) physical status I-II-III, scheduled for elective PCNL under general anesthesia were recruited for the study. Exclusion criteria included; BMI > 40 kg/m 2 Randomization and blinding Before PCNL operation the participants were randomly allocated to two groups by another expert who was not involved in the anesthesia management; Group RLB was RLB ( n n www.randomizer.org Protocol Standard monitoring procedures including pulse oximetry, 5‑lead electrocardiography and noninvasive blood pressure measurements were performed before anesthesia. Basal heart rates (HR) and mean arterial pressures (MAP) were recorded. General anesthesia was applied to both groups, and propofol (1.5-2 mg/kg), rocuronium (0.6–1.2 mg/kg), and fentanyl (3–4 µg/kg) were used for the induction of anesthesia. In addition, 1 µg/kg fentanyl can be re-administered for analgesia. In accordance with the ERAS protocol, 10 mg ondansetron is routinely used in PCNL each patient in our clinic to reduce postoperative complications and accelerate patient recovery. The patients were placed on their side, T9, T10 vertebraes were marked. After the skin was cleaned, the area was covered with sterile drape. A linear USG probe (6–13 Hz, Hitachi Europe Ltd, Tokyo, Japan) was placed in the center of the vertebral bodies to visualize the T9, T10 vertebrae. An anesthesiologist (experienced in RLB) performed the procedures using an in-plane approach with a USG-guided 1–15 Hz convex probe (8 − 4, Hitachi Europe Ltd, Tokyo, Japan). A puncture needle (21Gx100mm, USG-Type CCR, Vygon Co. Ltd. Ecouen, France) was inserted 1 cm from the probe at a 45-degree angle to the skin, targeting the lamina of the desired vertebra. And then suction from the needle by syringe., confirming the absence of blood or cerebrospinal fluid. 10 mL of 0.25% bupivacaine was injected posterior to each lamina (T9, T10), totaling 20 mL (Fig. 2  Fig. 1 Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials (CONSORT) flow diagram of the study.  Fig. 2 Skin surface anatomy landmarks for in-plane retrolaminar block and the entry of a needle, under USG- guidance coming into contact with the lamina. Outcome measures Demographic characteristics of all patients (age, weight, BMI, ASA, comorbidities), intraoperative characteristics (duration of surgery, blood loss, amount of opioid consumed, amount of urine per hour), HR and MAP were recorded before induction, after induction, after block, after 30 min, after 1 h and after recovery. Demographic data of the patients were obtained using the hospital data processing module and anesthesia records. In the postoperative period, the abdominal region of the patients was examined with a portable USG convex probe (6–15 Hz, Shangal International Holding Corp Ltd, Hamburg, Germany) in the operating room and in the ward. Peristaltic movements and gastric antrum examination were classified by Perlas Score (pre-induction, postoperative 1st, 3rd, 6th, 12th hour). No fluid in the antrum was scored as 0, minimal fluid in the right supine position was scored as 1, and tense antrum in both supine and right supine position was scored as 2 9 Sample size The sample size was determined before the start of the study, taking into account the following criteria: To determine the required number of participants for the study, we hypothesized that RLB could provide analgesia in PCNL. We calculated that at least 50 patients (25 in each group) were required to ensure with 95% confidence that the lower limit of the one-sided 95% confidence interval (or equivalently, the 90% two-sided confidence interval) would not fall below a noninferiority margin of -1 (given a significance level of 0.05). To account for potential dropouts, we enrolled a greater number of patients (28/30) than the calculated number in each group. Statistical analysis For the analysis of the study, data were entered into the Statistical Package for the Social Sciences (SPSS) software (IBM, SPSS version 27), and descriptive statistics were determined for each variable. The normality of the distribution of quantitative variables was assessed using the Kolmogorov-Smirnov test. For the comparison of quantitative variables with normal distribution between two independent groups, the Independent Samples t-test was used. For the comparison of non-normally distributed quantitative measurements between two independent groups, the Mann-Whitney U p Results A total of 67 patients were recruited to participate in this study. BMI: body mass index, ASA: American Society of Anesthesiologists, F: female, M: male, RLB: retrolaminar block, Control: control. Postoperative GI outcomes, including first flatus time (4.10 ± 0.87 h), first defecation time (20.96 ± 3.68 h), and I-FEED scores (2.35 ± 0.91) were statistically significantly lower in Group RLB. Postoperative time to first rescue analgesia was significantly longer in Group RLB (13.35 ± 4.06) compared to the control group. This finding, together with lower intraoperative opioid consumption and lower postoperative VAS scores in Group RLB, supports the conclusion that RLB provides effective analgesia in patients undergoing PCNL. RLB: retrolaminar block, Control: control, * p Discussion To our knowledge, this is the first randomized comparative clinical trial investigating the effects of RLB on postoperative GI in PCNL. The main mechanism of action of RLB for analgesia can be explained by the spread of local anesthetic from the superior costotransverse ligaments anteriorly into the paravertebral space, epidural spaces or intervertebral foramen 10 11 12 Retrolaminar block is a new regional analgesic block that can be used as an alternative to PVB. The injection of local anesthetic between the vertebral lamina and deep paraspinal muscles instead of between the parietal pleura and the costotransverse ligament makes RLB technically easier than PVB. For experienced practitioners in USG-guided regional anesthesia, the learning curve for the RLB technique is relatively short. Our USG experience has resulted in a low failure rate in RSB applications ( n 13 14 15 GI dysfunctions such as distension, PONV, slowed intestinal peristalsis, ileus, fatigue, delayed gastric emptying and delayed oral active eating may be seen. Postoperative GI dysfunction affects patients both physically and psychologically and negatively affects the healing process. In our study, intestinal peristalsis and gastric fluid volume status were scored by Perlas scoring with USG convex low frequency (2–5 MHz) transducer probe in supine and right lateral decubitus position at preoperative baseline, postoperative 1, 3, 6 and 12 h. Ke Peng et al. applied stellate ganglion block in patients undergoing posterior spinal surgery for thoracolumbar spinal fracture 7 16 17 3 Although RLB is increasingly used for postoperative analgesia in patients undergoing surgery 6 13 15 2 6 PCNL is an effective and safe method for the treatment of kidney stones. However, serious complications such as colon injury may occur rarely (0.3%) during the PCNL procedure, especially during percutaneous access to the kidney. Advanced age, low BMI, marked pelvic-lingual dilatation, megacolon and horseshoe kidney have been reported in the literature as factors that increase the risk of colonic perforation 18 19 Limitations: The study has several limitations. First, it was conducted in a single center, which limited the generalization of the results to other centers and different patient populations. Second, since the study focused on short-term results, further studies may need to be planned to evaluate the long-term effects of RLB on GI function (e.g., chronic gastrointestinal problems). In addition, some clinical assessments and some components of the I-FEED score include subjective elements in determining gastrointestinal function. The level of statistical significance can be increased by increasing the sample size. In this regard, future research with larger participant groups will enable us to better evaluate the applicability of our findings to different populations and clinical scenarios. Conclusion Retrolaminar block has shown positive effects on postoperative pain management, gastrointestinal tract function and hemodynamic stability in PCNL patients. Lower opioid consumption, faster bowel movements and longer-lasting analgesic effect improved patient satisfaction and provided adequate postoperative pain control. These findings support the use of RLB as a safe and effective analgesic method in PCNL surgery. .
